div1.p: Special Orders #39 directs a hospital steward and a private to assist Echeverria at the non-immune camp near Quemados, Cuba. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Military Orders for Rafael T. Echeverria, June 18, 1900
div1.p:
Adjutant General's
OFFICE,
JUL 2 1900
ROLLS DIVISION.
[unclear]

ORDERS, BOOKS, BLANKS & D.C. DIV.
A. G. O.
RECD. JUN 29 1900

FROM THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Vol 179 B 1900

HEADQUARTERS DEPARTMENT OF HAVANA
AND PINAR DEL RIO.
Quemados, Cuba, June 18, 1900.
Echeverria

SPECIAL ORDERS, }
No. 39. }

1. Private James Hayes, Company D, 8th Infantry, hav-
ing been tried by a general court-martial convened at Co-
lumbia Barracks, Cuba, and found guilty of absence from
11 P. M. Inspection, in violation of the 33d Article of War
(six previous convictions), was sentenced “To be confined
at hard labor, under charge of the post guard, for three (3)
months, and to forfeit ten (10) dollars per month for the same
period.”
The sentence is approved, and will be duly executed.

2. Private Charles P. Marshall, Company H, 8th U. S.
Infantry, having been tried by a general court-martial con-
vened at Columbia Barracks, Cuba, and found guilty of de-
sertion, in violation of the 47th Article of War (three pre-
vious convictions), was sentenced “To be dishonorably dis-
charged the service of the United States, forfeiting all pay and al-
lowances due him, and to be confined at hard labor, at such post
as the reviewing authority may direct, for one (1) year and six
(6) months.”

The sentence is approved, and will be duly executed, until
further orders, at Columbia Barracks, Cuba.

3. Private Charles C. Connors, Company D, 8th Infantry,
having been tried by a general court-martial convened at
Columbia Barracks, Cuba, and found guilty of desertion, in
violation of the 47th Article of War (five previous convic-
tions), was sentenced “To be dishonorably discharged the ser-
vice of the United States, forfeiting and pay and allowances due
him, and to be confined at hard labor, at such post as the re-
viewing authority may direct, for one (1) year and six (6)
months.”

The sentence is approved, and will be duly executed,
until further orders, at Columbia Barracks, Cuba.

4. Private John Tully, Light Battery F, 2d Artillery,
having been tried by a general court-martial convened at
Columbia Barracks, Cuba, and found guilty of selling arms,
in violation of the 17th Article of War (six previous con-
victions), was sentenced “To be dishonorably discharged the
service of the United States, forfeiting all pay and allowances due
him, and to be confined at hard labor at such post as the reviewing
authority may direct, for one (1) year and six (6) months.”

The sentence is approved, and will be duly executed,
until further orders, at Columbia Barracks, Cuba.

5. Pursuant to instructions contained in an endorse-
ment from Headquarters Division of Cuba, dated June 12,
1900, 1st Lieutenant Dwight E. Aultman, 2d Artillery, is
hereby appointed an acting ordnance officer for the purpose
of receipting for the Spanish ordnance and ordnance stores
pertaining to the Coast Defenses of Havana, and other ar-
ticles of ordnance referred to in an endorsement from
Headquarters Division of Cuba, dated May 5, 1900, which
endorsement directed 2d Lieutenant C. C. Carter, 2d Artil-
lery, to transfer his ordnance responsibility to the Chief
Ordnance Officer, Department of Havana and Pinar del
Rio.

6. Upon the recommendation of the Chief Surgeon, the
commanding officer, Columbia Barracks, will detail Acting
Hospital Steward G. G. Spurlin, U. S. Army, and one pri-
vate of the Hospital Corps, to report to Major Rafael Eche-
verria, Surgeon, U. S. Volunteers, in charge of non-immune
camp near Quemados.
BY COMMAND OF BRIGADIER GENERAL LEE:

R. E. L. MICHIE,
Assistant Adjutant General.
